coredata.dc:title: Correlation between intramolecular bond lengths and K-shell σ-shape resonances in gas-phase molecules
coredata.dc:creator: Sette, F.
Stöhr, J.
Hitchcock, A.P.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Analysis of K-shell excitation spectra of gas-phase molecules containing at least two atoms of either B, C. N. O or F reveals the existence of a striking correlation between the bond length of the atomic pair. the sum of their atomic numbers and the associated α-shape resonance energy. Empirical rules are established which allow the derivation of intramolecular distances with accuracies reliably better than ± 0.05 A from the K-.shell absorption spectrum of one of the atoms in the Molecule.

An example where the proposed relations can be successfully used for the determination of bond lengths is found in the C K-edge ISEELS spectrum of the per- fluoro-2-butene molecule (CF3-CF-CF-CF3). In this molecule the C—C single and double bond and the C—F bond distances are not known but are expected to be similar to tliose in the perfluoropropene mole- cule which are 1.53, 1.32 and 1.33 A, respectively. Using the experimental values of the observed o-shape resonances of 5 = 13.1, 1.0 and —1.4eV [14] we can derive a C—F distance of 1.30 A, a C—C double bond distance of 1.32 A and 1.54A for the C—C single bond. This example illustrates how the proposed rules can also be applied to quite complex molecules containing different bonds between different atomic pairs. In spite of the remarkable predictive power of the derived rules which demonstrates their practical reli- ability and internal consistency, we have to remember that the basic hypothesis on which the presented re- sults are grounded is a one-to-one correspondence be- tween the position of the a-shape resonance and a well- defined bond between two atoms. Molecules exist where this concept breaks down. Typical cases are N^O, N0^ and CO^ where the bonding orbitais are delocalized [15]. When the presented relations are ap- plied to these spectra [16,17], distances are found which are shorter (up to 0.3 A) than the real ones. With this caveat the derived rules offer for the first time a consistent and unified empirical correlation be- tween tlie energies of inner-shell a-shape resonances and the geometrical structure oflow-Z molecules. We are well aware that these correlations are by no means satisfactorily founded theoretically and hope that our observations will provide the stimulus for detailed the- oretical investigations.
